repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Some more changes that improve the limited API experience.

(Note that the tp_name one is already in review at #3693 )

comment_data.body: Maybe we should just handle declared builtin types differently, much earlier on. I mean, they don't need to be imported, for example. They are just statically there. This place here seems _very_ late for this distinction.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3537,9 +3539,14 @@ def generate_type_import_call(self, type, code, import_generator, error_code=Non
                 code.putln("")  # start in new line
             code.putln("#if defined(PYPY_VERSION_NUM) && PYPY_VERSION_NUM < 0x050B0000")
             code.putln('sizeof(%s),' % objstruct)
-            code.putln("#elif CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API")
-            code.putln('sizeof(%s),' % objstruct)
-            code.putln("#else")
+            if is_builtin_type:
+                # Builtin types are opaque in when the limited API is enabled
+                # and subsequents attempt to access their fields will trigger
+                # compile errors. Skip the struct size check here so things keep
+                # working when a builtin type is imported but not actually used.

comment_data.body: Yeah, we should guard this as well. There are more places like this, though. I've push cd3ce37dfbff134baa110437a0597cd5f8663d97 to master.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2808,9 +2808,13 @@ def generate_result_code(self, code):
             # PyObject_GetIter() fails if "tp_iternext" is not set, but the check below
             # makes it visible to the C compiler that the pointer really isn't NULL, so that
             # it can distinguish between the special cases and the generic case
+            code.putln("#if CYTHON_USE_TYPE_SLOTS")
             code.putln("%s = Py_TYPE(%s)->tp_iternext; %s" % (

comment_data.body:
I mean the the problem comes down to the fact that the `ctypedef class xxx [object yyy]:` construct is too powerful for the limited API. It gives cython code the ability to access fields within those types which is impossible to support in a limited API setting.

I think ideally cython should just `#error` when the source file containes such a `ctypedef class` and the user compiled in limited API mode. In practice that wasn't really possible because some modules do `cimport cpython.xxx` files that contain such `ctypedef`s (even though the modules at hand included them for some functions and not for the types).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3537,9 +3539,14 @@ def generate_type_import_call(self, type, code, import_generator, error_code=Non
                 code.putln("")  # start in new line
             code.putln("#if defined(PYPY_VERSION_NUM) && PYPY_VERSION_NUM < 0x050B0000")
             code.putln('sizeof(%s),' % objstruct)
-            code.putln("#elif CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API")
-            code.putln('sizeof(%s),' % objstruct)
-            code.putln("#else")
+            if is_builtin_type:
+                # Builtin types are opaque in when the limited API is enabled
+                # and subsequents attempt to access their fields will trigger
+                # compile errors. Skip the struct size check here so things keep
+                # working when a builtin type is imported but not actually used.

commit.message: Use PyIter_Next instead of tp_iternext without CYTHON_USE_TYPE_SLOTS

Avoid PyMethod_xxx functions when CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API

Based on Facebook D20309657

Consider builtin types as opaque when importing in limited API

cython supports a construct like this to declare members of object types:
```
ctypedef class __builtin__.py_long [object PyLongObject]:
    cdef digit* ob_digit
```

The generated code checks that `tp_basicsize` matches the size of
corresponding type struct. This does not work in the limited API in
which builtin type structs are opaque; this disables the test in that
case.

This helps code that contains such a `ctypedef` but does not otherwise
use the type.

Based on Facebook D20344150
